  One of the reasons why I felt my attention waver was the repetitiveness of Jude's nature. Although I understand it's meant to depict the severe condition in its truest forms and how his hardships have taken a toll on him, time and time again, reading the dark state Jude was stuck in, inadvertently made my empathy diminish as he refused to let others in. Obviously, easier said than done in real life, but in the story, it was reiterated several times that it was unnecessary to repeat it to get the point across. It would be a cycle of good things happening to him, taking a healthy step forward, only to be thrown 10 steps back. For instance, when Harry and Juliet adopted Jude, finally allowing him to experience a loving household, only to have him get entangled with Caleb, who made him relive his abuse mentally and physically.
  
  I remember reading up to the part when Willem realized he had feelings for Jude. Although I enjoyed the outcome, I wished more hints were given throughout the book from any of the characters' points of view. The lack of buildup made it seem abrupt and thrown in the mix of Jude's life. It was hard to differentiate whether Willem was simply being a good friend or if he had been interested all along. I wish more were shared about their initial stages of interest.
